concern:
My 2 year program has a cohort of 30 people and I feel like I’m always finding out about gatherings after the fact. Last semester, I consistently saw Snapchat/IG stories and updates on bar hang outs, games, and more literally every week. Sometimes even more. But they were usually during or after the event. I tried to participate but how am I supposed to attend if I had no idea it was happening? And it’d get awkward when I was asking “what’s going on?” or “what are you guys talking about?”. Someone once even said “Poor (my name), she keeps thinking there’s a group chat for this when we plan it spontaneously”. I just get left out because no one tells me. I get that I’m more introverted, but I really do try to talk and participate in conversations and have been mistaken as an extrovert by an extrovert before. I’ve really worked on this over the years. And other introverts in the class somehow also find out about the events, parties, and gatherings. 

Part of me felt ok - I tried to make myself feel better by saying that those people just don’t have a life outside of the program. And that I wanted to have more of a balance. Seeing the same people 5 days a week a day PLUS some evenings and most weekends is a lot! On top of 5-6 classes and student clubs and volunteering, I have a GA position, casual job, serious relationship, family, and other friends to balance. I feel ridiculous and in the minority for feeling this way. 

Now that it’s March, there seems to be less of these events happening second semester, but it still hurts when someone sends a video or picture (e.g. group selfie) to the cohort group text and it’s like almost everybody is in it. This literally happened last night at 2AM for someone’s st patty party. I can’t silent the notifications or not check because sometimes there are important announcements to know. I try to shrug it off and not let it get to me but I feel ashamed that I’ve cried over this before.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks. I've just been feeling a bit out of the loop with my cohort. It's like everyone knows about these hangouts except me, and it's getting to me more than I'd like to admit.
Therapist: It sounds like feeling left out is really weighing on you. How do you think being more connected with your cohort might change things for you?
I think being more connected would help me feel like I belong and not missing out on these experiences. It might make me feel more included and maybe build some stronger friendships with them.
That makes a lot of sense, wanting to feel a sense of belonging and connection. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding ways to become more connected with your cohort?
client: Honestly, I'd say maybe a 4 or 5. I want to connect more, but it feels like I keep missing the mark on how to actually make it happen.
It sounds like you're recognizing some challenges, but also a desire to strengthen those connections. What do you think might increase your confidence to move from a 4 or 5 to a higher number?

I guess maybe figuring out how they all know about these hangouts in the first place or maybe just being more proactive in asking about plans. It might help if I could get comfortable just putting myself out there more, even if it's a bit awkward.

Therapist: It sounds like you're considering some practical steps, like being proactive and stepping out of your comfort zone. What would it mean for you if you were able to take these steps and feel more connected with your cohort?
I think it would feel really rewarding, like I finally cracked the code or something. It’d probably boost my confidence and make me feel more like an actual part of the group instead of an outsider.
Feeling like a genuine part of the group sounds really important to you. What do you think is the biggest benefit you would experience if you felt more like an insider within your cohort?
I think I'd feel a lot more secure and happier overall. Like I wouldn't be second-guessing myself or feeling left out all the time, and maybe I'd even have more fun and less stress about missing out.
It sounds like feeling secure and happier is really significant to you. What do you think might be the most compelling reason for you to start taking those steps, given the benefits you envision?

I guess the biggest reason is I just want to stop feeling this anxiety and loneliness. If I could feel more connected, I think I could focus on my studies and everything else more without this weight hanging over me all the time.

Therapist: It seems like reducing anxiety and loneliness would have a big impact on both your personal well-being and academic focus. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel right now about your ability to take some initial steps towards feeling more connected?
client: Honestly, maybe like a 5 or 6? I know it’s something I need to work on, but I’m not completely sure how to start or if it'll even make a difference.

Therapist: It's understandable to feel uncertain about how to start. A 5 or 6 shows you have some confidence already. What small first step do you think could help you feel a little more connected to your cohort?

client: Maybe I could try reaching out to one or two people individually and see if they want to grab coffee or something. It feels less intimidating than trying to join a big group thing all at once.

That sounds like a thoughtful first step. Reaching out for coffee with one or two people can indeed feel more manageable and personal. Based on this, a possible option could be to set a goal to contact one person this week. How does that sound to you? What potential challenges do you foresee, and how might you overcome them?

client: Yeah, reaching out sounds doable. I think the biggest challenge might be figuring out who to ask first and finding a time that works for both of us. Plus, there's always that fear of rejection or it being awkward. Maybe I could start with someone I’ve chatted with a bit before to make it less intimidating.

Great, it sounds like you have a good plan in mind. Reaching out to someone you've already chatted with is a smart way to reduce that feeling of awkwardness. Remember, it's perfectly normal to feel a bit nervous, and taking this step shows your willingness to connect. Setting a goal to contact one person this week can be a great start. If you hit a roadblock, maybe remind yourself of the times when reaching out has led to positive outcomes in the past. You're doing a fantastic job by considering these steps to reduce loneliness and anxiety. As you move forward, if you face any more challenges or need to talk, I’m here to support you. Keep believing in yourself, and let's touch base next week to see how things unfold.
Thanks, I appreciate it. I'll give it a shot and see how it goes. I'll let you know how things turn out next week.
